entry.et: Middle English, from Latin fixus, past participle of figere to fasten; akin to Lithuanian dygti to sprout, break through

def.dt: :to make firm, stable, or stationary
:to give a permanent or final form to: as
:to change into a stable compound or available form bacteria that fix nitrogen
:to kill, harden, and preserve for microscopic study
:to make the image of (a photographic film) permanent by removing unused salts
:affix attach
:to hold or direct steadily fixes his eyes on the horizon
:to capture the attention of fixed her with a stare
:to set or place definitely :establish
:to make an accurate determination of :discover fixing our location on the chart
:assign fix the blame
:to set in order :adjust
:to get ready :prepare fix lunch
:repair mend fix the clock
:restore cure the doctor fixed him up
:spay castrate
:to get even with
:to influence the actions, outcome, or effect of by improper or illegal methods the race had been fixed
:to become firm, stable, or fixed
:to get set :be on the verge we're fixing to leave soon
:to direct one's attention or efforts :focus
:decide settle usually used with on had fixed on the first Saturday in June
:a position of difficulty or embarrassment :predicament
:the position (as of a ship) determined by bearings, observations, or radio
:a determination of one's position
:an accurate determination or understanding especially by observation or analysis
:an act or instance of improper or illegal fixing the fix was in
:a supply or dose of something strongly desired or craved a coffee fix
:a shot of a narcotic
:fixation
:something that fixes or restores :solution an easy fix
:refurbish fix up the attic
:to set right :settle fixed up their dispute
:to provide with something needed or wanted
:to arrange a date for
:an expedient usually temporary or inadequate solution to a problem
